title: Stephen Mlakic
text:
Stephen Mlakic (1844-1950), , was a <a href="Bosnian%20Croat">Bosnian Croat</a> born in <a href="Fojnica">Fojnica</a> who was a <a href="missionary">missionary</a> in <a href="Africa">Africa</a> among the tribes of <a href="Shilluks">Shilluks</a> and <a href="Nuers">Nuers</a> in Sudan, and, like his colleague <a href="Bernardo%20Kohnen">Bernardo Kohnen</a>, one of the most important representatives of Croatian <a href="African%20studies">Africanists</a>.
Besides his native Croatian he spoke <a href="German%20language">German</a>, <a href="Italian%20language">Italian</a>, <a href="English%20language">English</a> and <a href="Arabic">Arabic</a>, to which he added the language of <a href="Nilot">Nilot</a> tribe of Nuers. His letters to his brother (also a priest) in <a href="Bosnia%20%28region%29">Bosnia</a> witness about his very close contacts with Africans. It is worth to note his discovery that in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, near the town of <a href="Korsko">Korsko</a>, there is the village of Ibrim, where used to live <a href="Bosnian%20Muslims">Bosnian Muslims</a> inhabited there by an <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> <a href="sultan">sultan</a>. He donated a rich collection of artifacts of African culture to the <a href="Zagreb%20Ethnographic%20Museum">Zagreb Ethnographic Museum</a>.
He served as prefect of the <a href="Apostolic%20Prefecture%20of%20Bahr%20el-Gebel">Apostolic Prefecture of Bahr el-Gebel</a> in Sudan from October 21, 1938, until his death.
